title: Wednesday, 1st March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

hi

PM11:02am

It's one of those days that you are going to have to bear with

PM11:02am

Have approximately 10 plates in the air

11:02 am
PM11:02am

And a very difficult editorial call to make

PM11:02am

Concerning a story that an AV colleague is itching to publish

PM11:03am

But which may have consequences.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

That's cryptic.

PM11:03am

Yeah

PM11:03am

Can't be less so

11:03 am
BE11:04am

Fair enough. I'll clear my desk. I can take a hint.

PM11:04am

There's also been fresh Unilever stuff in the middle of the night Bryce

PM11:04am

Again it's stuff I can just blurt out here

11:04 am
BE11:04am

................... Right.

PM11:05am

Sorry

BE11:05am

So you're inviting the readership to speculate wildly? Cool. Okay.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

*can't

PM11:05am

It's made me think we should Sell Warren Buffett

PM11:06am

But that's not the sort of call you can make without having a proper think

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Dare we Sell the most successful investor of the modern age?

PM11:06am

That's a tough call

BE11:06am

Probably not on demonstrable performance, though it'd be good for click.

11:06 am
PM11:07am

But we don't farm clicks Bryce!

PM11:07am

Let me have a think

PM11:07am

But he can be our pic for today

11:07 am
PM11:07am

PM11:08am

Now he's discovered ML

undefined
11:08 am
PM11:08am

Anyway, it's a bull market

PM11:08am

70 points on the Footsie

PM11:08am

7333 on my screen

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Rocket

PM11:09am

Sorry for the tease, Rabble

PM11:09am

Really intended to give you something much firmer

11:09 am
PM11:09am

But stuff got in the way

PM11:10am

So Bryce -- we're back to krona down/stock up, yes?

BE11:10am

Actually -- we can say your Unilever tease it's nothing whatsoever to do with the initial scoop, right? Which remains what it is.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

The scoop is solid

BE11:10am

I note this only because I get a lot of wingnuts and conspiracy theorists chucking stuff at me.

PM11:11am

You are the anti-rainmaker

11:11 am
PM11:11am

You should go into business with Michael Klein

PM11:11am

Take Blair's slot

BE11:11am

Hm. Moving on from that theme ..........

11:11 am
PM11:11am

You'll make $$$$

BE11:11am

..... we have Vodafone mentioned on the right.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 200.50, down 1.4 (-0.69%), High: 202.45, Low: 200.40, Volume: 16.77m
11:11 am
BE11:12am

Which is .............. down?

BE11:12am

That's a little odd, given what's been said in Barcelona.

BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-96f8-3700c5664d30

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Vittorio Colao saying the merits of some kind of deal with Liberty are still valid.

BE11:13am

It is still an attractive combination. The deal is not on the table. But as a project, it’s an interesting project,

BE11:14am

And laying out the regulatory angle even before he's asked.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

If Europe wants the creation of real alternatives to incumbents, Vodafone and Liberty are the only two guys in town.

BE11:15am

From there we can go through the usual routine about Vodafone selling or spinning off or JV'ing the UK etc.

BE11:16am

Though we've been through that so often it feels like it should be in the price already. And the fact that Colao was able to talk about it openly -- as he seems to have been doing for much of 2017 -- is a pretty clear indication that nothing's happening right now.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

@Soundbuy: we're trying to track down Redburn's upgrade of Next this morning, but have failed so far.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 3,947, up 120 (+3.14%), High: 3,974, Low: 3,850, Volume: 411.49k
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Redburn research is so good, they rarely let anyone see it. That's as good a commercial model investment research has these days.

PM11:19am

Quite a brave call, even if we dont have the detail

PM11:19am

Next must have come off 20% or so since the new year

11:19 am
PM11:20am

Was pushing toward £50 at Xmas

BE11:20am

(@psudome: yep, that's my old colleague Jon Hopkins. Who hasn't chucked me the note, the sod.)

PM11:20am

Think Jefferies cut their target price yesterda

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Cut to £35

BE11:21am

Anyway, it's as good an excuse as any to mention this FCA rejig of the IPO regime.

PM11:21am

Tho they are on the fence with a 'hold'

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Finally caught up with our "Missing prospectus" theme

PM11:21am

The FCA that is

BE11:22am

https://www.fca.or...equity-ipo-process

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Finally realised they were being gamed by the City

BE11:22am

It all sounds fairly sensible at the headline .... as in, earlier prospectus and force the management to talk to independents.

BE11:23am

But it's not entirely clear how that second bit might work.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

(Though that's the reason for a consultation, obv.)

BE11:24am

I mean, does buyside research get pre-IPO access with sellside?

PM11:24am

Simply publishing the prospectus in a timely enough manner will be a huge step forward

11:24 am
PM11:24am

But you are right

PM11:24am

buyside has to get level playing field access

BE11:25am

And wouldn't that throw up a few conflicts with the big buyside houses who are already accused of getting favours around IPOs?

11:25 am
PM11:25am

You know this all goes back to the flotation of Orange in the late 90s

PM11:25am

(Yes, i am old enough to remember this stuff)

BE11:25am

I'm not. Go on.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Dresdner Kleinwort

PM11:26am

Basically barred all analysts from firms that were not on the IPO ticket

PM11:26am

Everyone was shocked and outraged

11:26 am
PM11:26am

But it was inside the rules

PM11:26am

The float was a disaster and effectively closed the London IPO market for XX months

PM11:27am

But the selective access thing stuck

11:27 am
PM11:27am

And here we are, 20 years later, and the regulator is finally taking action

PM11:27am

Actually, how slow do these guys move

PM11:27am

Fred from the comment desk has just been on -- he wants a piece from us later

11:27 am
PM11:28am

And ive just realised Ive already written it

PM11:28am

Multiple times

PM11:28am

Here's a spoiler

11:28 am
PM11:28am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-99cb-83242733f755

There is a certain absurdity to the latest Financial Conduct Authority findings on investment banking and the process of floating companies: apparently the banks have been managing information flows, curbing potentially critical coverage, so as to juice initial public offering prices. Investment banks have also been gaming the legal tables in the hope of attracting business.

Well, yes. It is encouraging that Britain’s financial regulator has noticed all this; it is a shame that it has taken so long.

PM11:28am

That's from last April

PM11:28am

https://www.ft.com...-99cb-83242733f755

11:29 am
PM11:29am

(Mouselet -- op-ed pages)

BE11:29am

Hm. Just thinking .... We'll also, I assume, have to unpick the IPO blackout agreements.

BE11:29am

Otherwise you have the implicit threat from any shunned house that they can put out "sell" advice more than a month before any bank that's put on the ticket can issue the inevitable "buy" advice.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Just say you had the sector's top-rated analyst: that's quite a big threat.

BE11:30am

Anyway, consultations are for this stuff. Let's see how it goes.

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:30am

ITV requested.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 206.94, up 4.44 (+2.19%), High: 209.40, Low: 201.00, Volume: 10.86m
BE11:31am

Numbers are ............ okay. Not great. In line.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

TD running slightly weaker, but expectations had been drilled lower by the media buyer feedback through December and January.

BE11:32am

Divi is a small positive surprise.

BE11:32am

Barclays to summarise.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

FY16 revenues grew 3.1% to £3,064m, 2% below our forecast and consensus. The miss vs our numbers was driven by Studios where external revenues climbed 12.8% to £932m, 4% (£42m) behind our estimate. Compared to consensus the miss was driven both by lower NAR and lower Studios revenues. ITV Family NAR declined 2.8% over 2016, below our expectation of -2.5% and ZoneFinance consensus of -2.1%% (Q4 was -6.2% below our -5.3%). Company guidance was for a decline of 3.0% in 2016E NAR.

Programming costs increased 5% to £1,050m, in line with our expectations.

EBITA increased 2.3% to £885m, 1% above Barclays and ZoneFinance consensus with both Broadcasting and Content doing slightly better than expected.

Headline Diluted EPS increased 4.1% to 17.0p, 3% ahead of our estimates and 2% ahead of consensus. The beat was due to slightly better taxes and interest.

ITV also announced a final ordinary dividend of 4.8p (2.4p interim ordinary already announced at 1H16 results) and a 5.0p special dividend, getting the FY total dividend to 12.2p, down 24% yoy. We were forecasting 11.2p with 4p of extraordinary.

BE11:33am

Conclusion

2016 was a bit better than expected but advertising guidance is worse for the first four months, implying that consensus (-3.7% for the FY) is unlikely to move back up, which some people were expecting owing to a better end to 2016. Taking into account the building blocks given by the company (cost savings, programming savings, investment etc), we believe consensus is unlikely to move. While this could be seen as a relief, the weak start to 2017 lead us to question full year consensus. Re-iterate Equalweight with 205p target.

BE11:35am

And I'm not sure there's anything interesting than that to be said.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:35am

Or at least dormant.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 234.10, down 2.3 (-0.97%), High: 238.90, Low: 228.30, Volume: 676.72k

PM11:36am

hmm

BE11:36am

PM11:36am

Ok, that's pretty much dead then

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We can ponder why they ever had an interest, but that's a horse we've flogged to death in previous sessions.

undefined
PM11:37am

This ZPG thing

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Who was saying 'get out" yesterday?

BE11:37am

UBS.

PM11:37am

They must be irritated by their lack of timing

11:37 am
ZPG PLC (ZPG:LSE): Last: 391.60, up 20.1 (+5.41%), High: 391.70, Low: 371.30, Volume: 255.21k
PM11:38am

ZPG Plc (LSE:ZPG) ("ZPG") owner of some of the UK's most trusted home-related digital platforms including Zoopla, uSwitch, PrimeLocation, Hometrack and Property Software Group today announces that it has acquired Expert Agent, following the announcement on 31 January that ZPG was in negotiations on a potential further acquisition.

PM11:38am

Established in 2003, Expert Agent was the first UK provider to take estate and letting agency software online and provides fully cloud-based software solutions and essential systems for the day-to-day management of inventory, marketing and communications for estate agents and lettings agents across the UK.

11:38 am
PM11:39am

Used in 2300 estate agents

PM11:39am

That actually doesnt sound like many

BE11:39am

This is all part of the reason why it turned into ZPG, of course.

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Google says there are 16,500 estate agents in Britain

BE11:40am

But ZPG is fated to be called "Zoopla owner ZPG", just as IAG is "British Airways owner IAG" .... Changing your name to an acronym to indicate you're a wider group only means you get identified by your biggest property.

BE11:40am

Let me grab some Jefferies on the deal.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

What was acquired: Expert Agent. Established in 2003, Expert Agent was the first fully cloud-based provider of estate and letting agency software. The product suite includes tools for the day-to-day management of inventory, marketing and communications for estate agents and lettings agents across the UK. It will operate as a stand-alone platform and brand, and the team of around 40 staff will become a part of the Property Services division of ZPG. We understand that Expert Agent has more than 16,000 users across more than 2,250 agency branches across the UK. Customers range from online start-ups to traditional agents with more than 100 branches

Why was it acquired? In the main, Expert Agent targets earlier stage and smaller agents than ZPG. This acquisition gives ZPG access to a segment of the market on which it had not previously focused, enhancing ZPG's product suite and offering Expert Agent's clients a one-stop shop upgrade path as they grow their businesses. We also expect that there will be cross-selling opportunities for the broader group.

The Agency software market. Much like the agency market it serves, the Residential Property Software market is highly fragmented with more than 100 companies competing in the market we estimate to be worth around £120m pa. PSG is the biggest player with a market share 3x that of its nearest rival and Expert Agent falls into the top 10, and we believe that the top 10 have a combined market share of about 60%.

Who is selling? Expert Agent is being sold by Metropolis Media, a company specializing in business and consumer media, and discount and loyalty programmes. The group has a range of titles, which we think have been featured on the satirical news quiz 'Have I Got News For You', including 'National Plant Hire Guide', 'Water Sewerage and Waste' and 'Packaging News'. Until today it had one software business, Expert Agent. Metrpolis had acquired a majority stake in Expert Agent in 2013.

How much was paid? The acquisition is small (not breaching any of the Class 2 Transactions disclosure tests). Essentially Expert Agent's revenue, profits, consideration (as % of ZPG's market cap) and gross capital are all less than 5% of ZPG's. We estimate that Expert Agent had revenues of around £4m in FY16 and due to it being a fully cloud-based system we expect that it generated a higher EBITDA margin that PSG.

Are we changing estimates? We are not changing estimates today. In the absence of any further RNS announcements, we will review our estimates when ZPG reports its half-year results.

BE11:41am

"Water Sewerage and Waste" .....

BE11:41am

There's good money in trade mags.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Valuation: At 372p, Zoopla trades on a CY2017E PER of 22.6x and EV/EBITDA of 17.8x. Our PT of 483p is based on DCF valuation weighted 50% to our Neutral Case, 40% to our Bull Case and 10% to our Downside Case.

undefined
BE11:41am

Oh, while on the sector ......

11:41 am
BE11:41am

This Purplebricks rerating continues apace.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 331.67, up 31.67 (+10.56%), High: 387.22, Low: 300.00, Volume: 1.88m
BE11:42am

........... Which ............... is ............................ odd.

I note in passing that shareholders have a vote coming up on the £50m fundraising

BE11:43am

Though to actually print the stock shareholders will have to waive their pre-emption rights.

11:43 am

BE11:43am

So, Woodford etc (one assumes) pay 220p for the benefit of all shareholders when the price is currently a quid higher?

11:44 am
PM11:44am

It's extraordinary

I mean, cash calls are always difficult to price, and this one was done without a discount so there's no shenanigans along those lines ......

PM11:45am

Just looking back at the placing announcement...

11:45 am

When you see lines like this..

PM11:45am

We are proud to announce our plans to launch Purplebricks in the US, a market we estimate to be worth some US$70 billion in annual estate agent commission.

PM11:46am

Omg smile

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Indeed ..... and .... well, if I were a Purplebricks holder I'd think carefully about whether my pre-emption rights were something it's worth voting to retain.

PM11:46am

It's a $70bn market so we only need a sliver to be wildly profitable

PM11:46am

No

11:46 am
PM11:46am

The US real estate market is weird and alien to anyone from the UK

undefined
BE11:47am

ROTR have hit this story:

11:47 am
BE11:47am

http://www.thetime...auritius-mljc8wfjv

BE11:47am

One of the City’s best-known fund managers and most pugnacious operators has moved to Mauritius as he seeks to escape the “noise” of the UK’s fevered investment community.

Terry Smith, former boss of Tullett Prebon and son of an East End lorry driver, has headed to the Indian Ocean island, popular for its luxury golf resorts and beaches. The veteran investor, who is known for his love of boxing, said he had been lured by the prospect of the peace and quiet allowing him to make better investment decisions.

“It is much more convenient in terms of its time zone than London for dealing in Asian markets, and I find being away from the ‘noise’ of London helpful,” he said yesterday.

PM11:48am

Wot? I'd missed this

11:47 am
BE11:48am

(More behind the paywall. Pay for your newspapers.)

BE11:48am

Look, it's because London's noisy.

BE11:48am

Not because it's taxy.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

He's quite clear on that.

PM11:48am

El Tel retired to a beach in the Indian ocean

PM11:48am

I can see the attractions

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

@dorsetcontrarian, I think, was talking about consumer staples and margins and such.

BE11:50am

Which leads us into a huge sector note this morning from Charlie Mills of Credit Suisse.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

He's keen on gaspers, not food.

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,825, up 31.5 (+0.83%), High: 3,860, Low: 3,813, Volume: 586.41k
BE11:50am

............. gets an upgrade.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

It's all quite top-down, but there's some interesting stuff in there about the death of big brands

BE11:51am

......... and whether the strategy of running companies hot will ultimately damage them.

BE11:52am

Going to dive into the middle of the note and quote a particularly readable bit:

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Historically the barriers to entry in Staples were almost insurmountable for would-be entrants. 95% of the advertising was on the TV (expensive) and the distribution was either though supermarkets (expensive), required access to whole distribution or a direct distribution system. Getting in front of the consumer was difficult and expensive.

That has changed.

5 years ago the multi-nationals when asked about competition really only referred to each other. Now everyone of them when asked talks about local competition being the biggest challenge ahead of the International peers. The speed, flexibility and access to market has changed, as has the consumers appetite for diversity, local, craft, organic, natural, sourced, etc. The ground is moving fast.

BE11:53am

Historically the rule was the big get bigger, and the market shares of the middle tier get increasingly squeezed for shelf space. This has not been the trend for the last 5 years – indeed the reverse has been true.

In developed markets, we view the trend toward "real food" as a primary reason for the steady decline in Big Food's market share. "Real food" advocates seek more transparency in the food they eat. They read ingredient label carefully, and they actively limit their consumption of artificial flavors, preservatives, added sugars, and refined grains. Basically, they say they won't eat packaged foods from a box unless the ingredient list is less than five ingredients long. A large percentage of real food" advocates are Millennials,
who generally steer away from mainstream brands. Whole Foods brought "real food" into the mainstream, and the major grocery chains made huge improvements to their organic foods sections to catch up. Smaller, more entrepreneurial competitors in the "middle tier" like Chobani, Annie's (now owned by General Mills) and KIND have created billion brands by capitalizing on this trend magnificently. The Dollar Shave Club took 5% of the market from P&G.

BE11:53am

The conundrum for the big food companies is that all of their scale in manufacturing, R&D, and marketing is geared toward using cheap ingredients to optimize taste and convenience and the lowest possible cost to the consumer. For example, Kraft literally invented pasteurized processed cheese for the purpose of extending shelf life and limiting the need for refrigeration. As a result, the idea of "Kraft Organic cheese" almost sounds like a contradiction in terms to consumers. Consumers are more willing to try niche “homespun” brands when seeking “natural” and “organic” solutions as opposed to the big corporate brands. Local wins over global?

Another striking example of local gaining at the expense of global/national is the rise of craft beer in the US – big beer has lost significant ground to these local start-ups whose combined share has tripled in 6 years.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Here's that in graph form.

BE11:54am

BE11:54am

........... So, in terms of solutions. Strip out costs or try and pretend you're not what you are.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The poster child for which is Kraft-Heinz, of course. Margins by 1,000 bps to nearly 30% since the takeover.

BE11:56am

(And it's done that to a large extent by cutting trade spend -- the undisclosed grey where suppliers wholesale the their retailers' discounts, promotions, listing fees.)

PM11:56am

I'm trying to picture craft ciggies

11:56 am
BE11:57am

(@Maverick: be careful please. This is not a bulletin board.)

PM11:57am

But can't

BE11:57am

........ So, M&A. Both for the big stuff, to take out costs, and the small stuff, to add brands not tainted by the stink of big commerce.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

... in the latter category:

BE11:57am

BE11:58am

None of which is risk free.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

[T]here a risk that a heavy focus on ‘returns’ means investment in category development/innovation is restrained, brand equity insidiously degrades and demand is not as strong as it otherwise might be? Buffett describes 3G as "extraordinarily successful at eliminating unnecessary costs" but, in an industry where the return on 'demand generation’ investment is notoriously difficult to measure [half my advertising is wasted, I just don't which half] and where brands don’t immediately suffer from neglect, can we be
sure the 3G scalpel is not cutting into muscle rather than fat? Unilever has suddenly found 40bp of margin this year (in response to Kraft Heinz’s aborted approach). We hope/assume this is an admission that they have simply not been as aggressive on cost cutting as they could have been?

BE11:59am

Anyway, good note. Worth your time.

undefined
11:59 am
PM11:59am

I will try and usual place it later

BE12:00pm

(@Doodle: no it didn't.)

BE12:00pm

(It took a minority stake in 2001.)

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

BE12:01pm

BE12:01pm

FRANCOIS FILLON STAYS IN FRENCH PRESIDENTIAL RACE

12:01 pm

BE12:02pm

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

BE12:05pm

BE12:06pm

12:06 pm
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 965.25, up 14.25 (+1.50%), High: 967.50, Low: 953.50, Volume: 1.53m
BE12:06pm

(Cantor's pushing it today, also.)

BE12:06pm

EZJ offered a cautious outlook for the year in its recent 1Q statement. Consensus forecasts have been cut and the stock is down. We now think that the risks to earnings from capacity growth by rival carriers and weak Sterling are fully priced-in. Demand for leisure travel is holding up well and disruption to operations from air traffic control strikes is muted. We cut our forecasts at 1Q and these are unchanged in this note. Our estimates are conservative versus consensus, and against through-the-cycle margins. EZJ’s fundamentals remain sound. In particular, fleet expansion plans are flexible if market conditions deteriorate. EZJ’s valuation is not challenging, trading on a calendar 2017 PE of 10.7x vs. an historic average of 15x; a c.30% discount. We upgrade to BUY from HOLD.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

(@ROTR: if we had any reason to believe the Exxon-BP rumour we would've mentioned it before 12.07pm. Calm the hell down, I suggest.)

BE12:08pm

Time to close?

PM12:08pm

Yeah

12:08 pm
PM12:08pm

Thanks for that tho.

PM12:09pm

Cheers for joining us on the right

PM12:09pm

Another request: DON'T TYPE IN BLOCK CAPS. THE SYSTEM BLOCKS THEM AND I HAVE TO GO IN THE BACK END AND FIX

12:10 pm
PM12:10pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp

PM12:10pm

Cheers

PM12:10pm

Bye

11:35 am
